Posted: February 5, 2014
												A fantastic addition to the series! They take a lot of the strengths from the first game and keep them in place, but they also take a bunch of the weaknesses as well and greatly improve them. In comparison, this game is much easier than Alan Wake but I had so much fun playing it the difficulty nerf didn't really bother me. Finally there is a larger selection of weapons, but to be honest my favorites ended up being the standard issue 9mm pistol, and the crossbow, together they got the job done clean and quickly. If you are familiar with the predecessor to this game, the flash bangs and flare gun have been nerfed as well, but with a decent amount of balance. Ammo conservation isn't nearly as pertinent in this edition with the abundant and refilling ammo caches in each zone. Exploring isn't nearly as nerve racking or dangerous as well, which is a bit of a letdown.********ATTENTION: POSSIBLE SPOILERS AHEAD********The story of this game is solid, but also unoriginal. The whole idea of a repeating day has been done a lot, but it somewhat fits in with the setting of Night Springs that the game presents. Still not 100% sure if this is just another episode, or if it actually happened. Either way, the change of setting is very welcomed and the new enemies are a nice addition. I do enjoy the idea of dealing with a doppelganger though, and Mr Scratch pulls it off VERY well, I actually really like the guy.********END OF POSSIBLE SPOILERS********As for rating, on an enjoyment level I would give this game a solid 8.5 / 10 if you are just in it for how fun the game is. If you want to be a stickler and rate the actual level of design and originality in the game, it would have to be a 7 / 10. Either way, this is still a damn good game, especially if you played Alan Wake.

												An improvement over the original game's double-DLC epilogue that, despite ending great-ish, left me with mixed feelin's. AN's story as it relates to AW boggled the mind, but it's still damn good in the realm of video games; more self-aware flirtations with storytelling tropes, this time more thoroughly entrenched in AW's schlocky influences.The story's 'bout half the length of AW's, but feels far shorter due to the limited scope & # of explorable environments. 3 maps, each repeated 3 times in a time loop. I tend to hate time loop stories, but this one left a mostly pos. impression. It's reasoning is believable in the context of the story, but that doesn't stop it from occas. feeling like a sad excuse to lengthen the game. (I love the changes b/w repeats, e.g., NPCs recognizing you and starting to understand their places in the loop--esp. the scientist's 4th-wall commentary on being unable to remember anything outside of her purpose in Wake's story.)Out of room. Solid continuation.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Alan's Wake American Nightmare is the pseudo follow-up/se to the well received Alan Wake. It is a 3rd person shooter which controls exactly the same as the first game. American Nightmare improves drastically on one of the few low points of the original Alan Wake, the combat. A.N. adds several new weapons and enemy types. These additions would have been welcome earlier, since it grew tiresome using the same 4 weapons in Alan Wake and fighting the same enemies over the 10 hours the game took to beat. However, I could see how the weaponry might not have fit in that atmosphere. The variations in the enemy types help keep the combat fresh as you continue through the estimated 3-4 hour campaign.The real standout in Alan Wake, the story, really takes a backseat in American Nightmare to the improved combat. While it will catch your attention at the beginning, I eventually found myself just wanting it to be over. Most of that I believe is due to the Groundhog Day esque nature of this installment, where you will be going through some of the same areas and events multiple times. It just fails to really engross you all the way through like Alan Wake did.Speaking of the environments, they are a nice change of pace from the Pacific Northwest. The events take place in Night Springs, Arizona, a fictional town which is the setting of an in-game TV show. You will be running around through some desert landscape for a few hours, but this game is shorter so it doesn't wear out its welcome like the forest did.The graphics have seen a slight improvement from the previous game, with the character animation looking much better, but still not stellar. The sound is also fantastic once again, with some great soundtrack moments during some battles.I would recommend American Nightmare to fans of the original Alan Wake for two reasons. If you liked the combat, which some did, you will love the additions to the weaponry and enemies. If you liked the story, which most did, you will be interested in finding out what happens next to our protagonist. If you have not played Alan Wake, I would recommend picking that up before trying out American Nightmare. There are too many spoilers for the events of the first game, and it would ruin the experience.Grade: B-

Posted: December 28, 2014
												American Nightmare is a follow-up to Alan Wake, which for the record I found surprisingly enjoyable, if decidedly corny. Originally a short DLC game on consoles, it was developed on a limited budget that really shows. But the way they used that budget is clever.To spoil mildly, this game involves you replaying a series of events a la Groundhog Day, so if the idea of repetitive content really bugs you, you may want to stay away. But the way it handles each loop is clever, with surprises I didn't expect and and awareness of it all that works, and so I'm generally willing to forgive them using that premise to squeeze extra playtime out of a relatively small environment. Game play for the most part mirrors Alan Wake, though there's a bit more of an emphasis on the gunplay, but with the standard survival horror need to conserve resources when possible. It's decent, but the same issues come back - it's a bit repetitive, and Alan can have trouble with camera angles, but he has more firepower and tricks this time around, which mitigates it slightly.Like its predecessor, it uses light well as a mechanic, particularly towards the end, and offers up a cheesy b-movie 90s horror feel obviously inspired Stephen King's Dark Half. The ending just kind of trails off much like Alan Wake, which may frustrate some. It's not for everyone, and I feel like my recommendation is more tenative than that for Alan Wake itself, but if you enjoyed Alan Wake, this is worth taking for a spin.

Posted: August 12, 2015
												I'm a huge fan of the Alan Wake universe and the lore Sam Lake/Remedy created with the first game, so of course I absolutely loved American Nightmare. Being quicker paced and more action packed with a large variety of weapons, including a nail gun and assault rifle, American Nightmare is a pulp fiction video game galore. It's pulp fiction because of how it's told, the narrative is that Alan Wake wrote himself into an episode of Night Springs just so he can slip into reality from the darkness and kill Mr. Scratch, the doppleganger that appears at the end of Alan Wake. I absolutely love the art style Remedy approached when recreating a sort of desert town in Arizona, the canyons, cacti, shrubs, and red rocks really stand out. Textures could be higher quality, but originally being an XBLA game, I'm assuming they had to consolidate the sizes. A shame they didn't go all out on the PC port though. Another thing I enjoyed was the semi-open world they layed out. The game is split into three areas, the Motel area, Observation tower area, and the drive-in theater. Each of the levels are rather small, but open enough that you can explore to find the manuscript pages and take in the details.Basically, I really liked this game. It could have been longer, and the textures could have been higher quality, but I understand that they weren't able to make American Nightmare a full game as Microsoft wanted Remedy to start working on the upcoming Quantum Break, which I hope comes to PC. The ending of Nightmare leaves me wanting more though, I need to find out what happens to Alan Wake. I just hope Remedy makes the long awaited sequel some day.9.0/10

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												Amazing standalone DLC in the Alan Wake franchise and while it is not a true sequel it does tie up the Mr. Scratch/Dark Half plotline introduced near the end in the original Alan Wake. They now also introduce more weaponry and enemies which makes the combat more interesting and they have also improved the graphics. It's still a very narrative game with a great Stephen King-esque feel to it. It still feels as if you are walking around in a Stephen King horror novel. The protagonist and an outside person narrate the events happening in-game and this is a very interesting design choice and it appealed very much to me as it immersed me more and made the feeling as if you were playing a character in a horror novel even more apparent. If you liked the original I'm almost certain you will like this game as well, it's a great game to enjoy for the wait for Alan Wake 2 and it didn't divert much from the original story we just see a glimpse in the life of Alan after the 2 years he spent in the dark place.I give this game an 8/10 just because it has a great way to tell it's story, has beautifull aestethics, great graphics and a compelling story.

 This is my opinion of Alan Wake's American Nightmare   Aspect Rating   Story 4.5   Graphics 8.0   Sound 8.5   Gameplay 7.0   Overall 7.0  Scores are out of 10. Overall score is an average The game looks as good as the first game but with a few small bugs here and there, but overall it's a fine looking game.The game's sound effects and ambient noise do an excellent job of setting the stage and helping create some atmosphere, but the written dialogue is a little ham-fisted.The game's heavy on the action elements, and the controls handle themselves admirably and make for a fun action experience. The story mode is a bit too repetitious, unfortunately. The story mode will take you about 4 hours, depending on if you hunt down all of the manuscript pages, while Arcade Action will keep you busy for a bit. I dont recommend this game at full price, but when on 75% discount, be sure to pick up your copy of Alan Wake's American Nightmare.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Its sort of a little adjunct story to the main Alan Wake tale.  They fix some of the nagging combat issues from the main game with a hammer called uzi, and that can be kind of fun... but... its one of those tradeoffs where there may be plenty of survival, but is there really that much horror when you have assault rifles and mag fed 9mm pistols etc? There was something (albeit admittedly something frustrating) to be said for the tension of frantically hand loading individual revolver rounds as the shadows closed in on you.Where as the main game you slogged through the combat for the story, this almost takes the opposite approach... they spice up the combat but the story is a little less... riveting.  Its not terrible, its just not going to live up to the main game there.  All in all its a decent little diversion for Alan Wake fans, but I wouldn't chalk it up as a must play.(7/10)

content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												I am not sure why the score on this game is so much lower than the original Alan Wake.  This is not a 50 or 60 dollar game like the first Alan Wake was,  so expecting it to live up to the first game is foolish.  You definitely get your moneys worth in this game. I personally used the -developermenu command to start my first play through on Nightmare.  Playing it on Nightmare the game still only took maybe 6 hours to complete, but it was a great 6 hours.  For the Price you can not go wrong. In this game Alan is caught in a time loop, where you have to complete the same set of objectives in the same environments 3 different times to "get it right"  Perhaps this was one of the downsides of the game for some people,  I personally found it to be a fresh new approach , and really enjoyed it.  I give this a 9 out of 10 based on what it is,  it was never released as Alan Wake 2 and I feel like a lot of the lower reviews and scores were based on that idea, rather than this being a much more affordable addon adventure.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Alan Wake's American Nightmare is the 2nd game in the Alan Wake franchise. Although it is a standalone product on Steam, it plays more like an expansion pack to Alan Wake than a direct sequel. The story is shorter and far less compelling, but the action, gameplay, and graphics are all beefed up a bit and actually a lot more fun than Alan Wake. The Good:* Low price tag, the game is $10 base and frequently goes for $5 during Steam sales.* Rather than walking down a hallway with the occasional monster (which is the original Alan Wake in a nutshell), American Nightmare features a more open-world. That being said, the game-world is incredibly small and features only three locales: a rest stop, an observatory, and drive-in theatre.The Bad:* The arcade mode, which is supposed to be one of the main draws of this game, is flat and not fun. It's very similar to Resident Evil's "Mercenaries" mode, where you simply run around and try to kill monsters in combos. However, Resident Evil somehow manages to be more fun and feel faster-paced.* Some art objects were taken directly from the original Alan Wake and stand out.The Ugly:* Being from Arizona, where the game is set, there were way too many noticeable errors. We don't have license plates on the front of our cars. There are Saguaro Cactuses in our deserts. There are not tall deciduous trees. I understand the location is a fictional town created in Alan's head, but I really don't care. I choose to be outraged!The Verdict:American Nightmare is short and sweet, and fixes almost everything that was wrong with the original Alan Wake. Since most people buy both games together, I kept this review short. However, if you have to pick one of the two, I would definitely tell you to get American Nightmare. Keep in mind, though, that American Nightmare does NOT compare to many other AAA shooter titles - it is fairly generic and won't offer you a revolutionary experience.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												Alan Wake's American Nightmare can be considered a short sequel to the first Alan Wake game as it picks up directly after The Signal and The Writer episodes.In general, the shooting mechanics and movement feel more crisp and smooth, there is an expanded variety of weapons to use, although most of them function similarly. (Mainly being: High Damage Single Shot, Low Damage Machine Gun or High Damage Shotgun Shot)In the first game, Flashbangs and Flare Guns used to be the ultimate weapons as they can easily clear all enemies in an area. This is not the case in the sequel. They are only able to take out some weak enemies while their main function is to disable enemies and clear off the darkness.The story component is short, about 1/3 the length of the original Alan Wake.However, there is a Arcade mode which puts you in 5 distinct settings and challenges you to score as many points as possible through defeating enemies and maintaining your streak by avoiding damage.If you enjoyed Alan Wake, this sequel is great fun. Just take your time to explore the areas and listen to the dialogue for a more detailed understanding of Alan Wake's world.  If you did not enjoy Alan Wake, this sequel will not interest you much unless you would really love to try out the improved shooting mechanics and the new enemy types.If you are thinking about playing either, Alan Wake is a better introduction to the series.My review of Alan Wake can be found here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/fenghuang/recommended/108710/

I would highly recommend you play this game, its short, it catches you and, it has one of the best stories in video games I've ever played.Story: 7/10+Remedy always knows how to tell a story, the story is amazing+Do not need to play Alan Wake to understand Alan Wake's American Nightmare+Characters are believable and Matthew Porretta did amazing job as Alan Wake+The ending is touching and worth the game-The story is repetitive though, as you get sent back to the beginning by your evil version back and you must rewrite the story over and over and over again till you get EVERYTHING right which is its biggest faultEnvironment: 7/10+Beautifully designed and great detail+Dark atmosphere with limited light matches the game SO WELL+From the cafe to the observatory to the drive in, everything is beautifully designed+Though the game is linear, it does allow A LOT of exploration in each level and actually kinda recommends it as you get better weapons, you must find manuscripts and to go deeper in the story, you must find TVs where your evil self recommended himself-Felt like this game would have been better as an open world game thoughControls: 10/10+Controller enabled+Fluent and comfortable, works well, no complaints+Recommend playing with controllerGameplay: 7/10+Combat is amazing, so beautifully done+Ammo is just perfect where you will run out of ammo for one or two gun(s), but not all+Added a survival mode with perfectly designed maps-[SPOILER Final battle was... too easy for how climatic it was]Multiplayer: 0/10-None-This game would have been amazing if it had a co-op for its multiplayer-Seriously? content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												So, Alan Wake returns to fight his evil twin who is trying to block out the sun and take over Alan Wake's life....sounds about right. So I knew going into this that it was going to be a short experience since it is not a sequel but instead a little side story. Knowing this still didn't prepare me for this watered down version of the original game, the story is pretty straight forward with very little room for exploration, characters are for the most part uninteresting with nothing really important to contribute to the story or experience (almost robotic at times), and the repeating of the same 3 levels 3 times was getting me to the point of not wanting to finish the game. Ok so it may seem that I am coming right out the gate with all the negatives but I did enoy this game and I'm going to justify it. Even though you repeat the same 3 levels 3 times over, which at first disappointed me, but near the end I felt they handled it the best they could, with each time you play that level it was a different experience because the characters sort of knew what was going on and helped speed the process of completing the level. Everytime you went back they completed some of the tasks that you had to complete yourself the time before. The graphics are beautiful just like in the original but this time it didn't have as many post card type scenes to look at. Gameplay and combat are the same from the original with Alan Wake not being the most agile guy in video games but it felt right for the context of the Alan Wake universe. Manuscripts this time around serve more of a unlock system rather than just a piece of additional pieces of information about the story, if you collect enough manuscripts you can open weapon boxes that are laid out around the environment which give you more powerful guns to help you proceed a little faster through that game (ex. SMG's, Assualt Rifles, and Hunting Rifles). They also added a few more enemy types that are very welcomed, nothing worse than fighting the same enemies over and over again. Aside from the story mode, they have Arcade Mode, this is like a horde mode that you defeat the Taken until the sun comes up (10 minutes), it was fun but I do feel like it was a missed opportunity for co-op or multiplayer, which it weird because usually I'm the one that doesn't want multiplayer in story driven games like Assassin's Creed and Mass Effect. But in this case it would've been nice, especially since you only play it to get the highest score on the leaderboards.That's pretty much it without spoiling the game, I do recommend it for people who like Alan Wake or for people who never played it before, it is a good game with a couple disappointments here and there but nonetheless a great game to play for a few hours.

You just have to survive for 10 minutes in some random location while dealing with ghostmen.. it's hard, but it's boring. I wish they would have implemented multiplayer on that part.-----------------------------------------------Now here is what i didn't like about the game:- Confusing story?- Automatic weapons- Different ghostmen, but you ahve to deal with them the same way- A little too cozy/They removed the atmosphere effectsI don't really know how to feel about the story, it's confusing and  you have to run through the same areas 3 times.. that's right.. 3 times. Also, if you played the original.. you know how to deal with these guys. content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Alan Wake's American Nightmare is an interesting title. A psuedo-sequel/spin-off/expansion to the psychological thriller "Alan Wake," American Nightmare is both familiar and different from it's parent. It's familiar in the sense that the core of the gameplay remains the same: you still use light to burn away protective darkness to make enemies vulnerable. Light is your ally, your friend. What's changed however, is the setting, your abilities, and the nature of the areas you'll traverse.American Nightmare is set in the American Southwest—Arizona, to be exact—outside a fictional city known as Night Springs. Unlike Alan Wake, which presented the player with mostly clear point A-to-B setpieces, American Nightmare follows a more open route. Although each of the areas you'll explore isn't exactly large (the developers are clearly feeling the crunch of being restricted by XBA's size limit), you're free to roam them as you please while you accomplish your objectives, and it's usually in your best interest to do so—provided occasional darkness attacks don't prove to muc for you.Fortuitously, however, Alan Wake is no longer the out-of-shape writer with a limited weapon selection he was before. In American Nightmare, he's changed himself to a more contemporary action-hero, with far more agility and skill than last we saw him. You'll find your arsenal expanded as well: sawn-off shotguns, Uzi's, Magnums, crossbows, even nail guns ... All will be needed. It's not an awe-inspiring set, but as you make your way through the game unlocking new weapons on the way to the final showdown, you'll definitely find some favorites.The story is short (and involves a time loop, to save space once again) so you'll get used to seeing the same scenes in the basic game. Fortunately, there's more to American Nightmare.Those weapons you unlock in the main game (via finding manuscript pages)? Once you've unlocked them, you can find them in Alan Wake's other mode: Arcade. Here you're tasked with lasting ten minutes on one of several maps, using whatever you can scrounge from nearby. The generic maps aren't too challenging, but once you've beaten a few, you'll unlock a new mode that ramps the difficulty up to eleven and probably past that becomes quite intense. Trying to use your flares and flashlight to hold the horde of enemies back while frantically reloading is a blast.From the standpoint of a newcomer, this title could be hit or miss. I recommend it, but Alan Wake seems to be a polarizing cup of tea for many. If you're a fan of action-survival modes (CoD Zombies, Gears Horde, Resident Evil Mercenaries) than American Nightmare is worth grabbing for the Arcade alone. Otherwise, I'd recommend watching a few videos first and seeing if the gameplay style appeals to you. For me, it does.Pros:—Clever enemy design—Unique Light-based combat—Exhilrating Arcade mode—Excellent soundtrack courtest of "Old Gods of Asgard" (AKA Poets of the Fall)—Genuine psychotically eerie villain, even if he is a hamCons:—Repetitive Environments—Limited types of enemies, even if they are clever—A little too much focus on conventional weapons over the light based ones—I did miss the more powerful flashlights from the original title.Recommendation: Buy it if you're a fan of the genre or a fan of Alan Wake, watch first otherwise. Definitely fun though.

												Pretty good followup to Alan Wake. I finished it with all the collectables within 6 hours, but enjoyed all of it. The game retains the same combat mechanics as the first title, and throws in a few new refreshing additions, such as new weapons, new enemies, and a different style of boss fights. Just like the first game, the storytelling is strong. This time, live action is used more heavily. All the cutscenes are done surprisingly well in live action, and there are a lot more ingame tv bits of Alan talking crazy. The cutscenes and Alan's dialogue/manuscript readings are great to listen to. The game is much shorter this time around with only three levels, which cleverly repeat themselves over the course of 3 Acts. There is also an Arcade mode apart form the main Story mode. It resembles a typical survival mode of some zombie killing game. You can avoid it.Overall, another good game by Remedy. It's a nice short extension to the Alan Wake storyline if you feel you need more of it after beating the first.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												The American nightmare picks up a couple of years after the events of the first game. Alan is still trapped in limbo - in the dark place, but evidently some parts of his mind attempt to escape the hold of the darkness. When he was first touched by darkness he spawned Mr. Scratch - an evil but charismatic,enigmatic as well as a "better" version of himself as Mr. Scratch himself put it.Mr. Scratch is trying to get out into the world and replace Wake who is thought dead by everyone except Barry. Wake finds himself in Arizona where weird phenomena keeps happening. He finds himself in a horror episode created by Mr. Scratch. ok, no more spoilers but there are a couple of twists in the story, and then there are more...twists..again and again....There are only three more characters in the game so it feels pretty desolate. Pretty soon the game turns into an arcade shoot. The ammo is plentiful (there are actually ammo and supply respawns throughout the game), the open-worldliness of the first map kinda takes away the feeling of accomplishment. You keep looking for the pages of the manuscript that Wake keeps writing in the dark place and use it to unlock better weapons as well as knowledge about what to do next.There are about 5 new enemies. There are spiders, there are those who can split into multiple versions of themselves, those who can stand 9 feet tall and wild large chain saws, those who turn into birds and those who can throw stink bombs, I guess.What's interesting is how you are able to pick up on the events of the world through radio shows and disturbing camcorder videos done by Mr. Scratch which were an absolute blast to watch and there are plenty of them. They used plenty of live video here which is unheard of in 99% of games. I also particularly enjoyed the determinism vs. free will arguments between Wake and the astronomer as well as on the radio. Wake basically argued that the absence of free will is irrelevant given the fact that the character knows nothing about the next set of set deterministic events.In any case the atmosphere is there, but it also feels kind of cheap, the desert is just too boring. I also found myself disinterested for the first couple of hours but then I kept playing and kept getting sucked in. It took me about 5.5 hours to finish the game. The game also does a pretty good job of explaining why the first game looked [played] like a TV show or a drama/thriller movie. Wake explains that he is able to fight the Taken effectively (and dodge attacks) because that was a small semi-realistic kernel of the main protagonist that helps propel the story forward. So many more things can make sense now for those who didn't really get the original game.There is also a survival mode. You are given 10 minutes to fight off the taken at various locations until the sunrise. It can be fun but I doubt you will be playing it more than a few times. I put the game into the hard category because there are a few frustrating spots in the game (especially the last 20 minutes) but you do feel pretty good when you survive multiple attacks with the last few bullets.All in all. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoyed the first game.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												It would be hard for me to talk about American Nightmare without touching on the original Alan Wake, because it very much feels like DLC that got spun into its own game. Alan Wake's strengths were its story, pacing, and graphics. The combat was a bit of a toss-up between decent and monotonous, depending on who you asked. American Nightmare is a shorter, weirder story told across three mostly open areas that you visit multiple times. The visuals are still sharp, but lose a lot of the atmosphere that Alan Wake had... the open desert just doesn't have the same creep factor as the dark woods, at least not as it's shown here. Dialogue is pretty snappy and clever, but it's propping up a story that really adds nothing to the themes introduced in Alan Wake.So the main draw is the combat, and to its credit, it's a little more interesting than in Alan Wake. Enemy encounters are varied in makeup, and there are some new foes like ones that split if you shine light on them and creepy jumping spider things. All the original weapons are here, along with new additions like a nailgun, uzi, and carbine. You can unlock weapon cases with additional weapons by finding manuscript pages scattered around which encourages exploration, but honestly as large as the areas are, there's not much to find. Enemies only appear as you follow the main plot, and the game showers you with ammo and flare, more than enough to handle any situation. I tried playing on the harder of the two difficulties and the battles were still a breeze with all the resources I had, but I could be killed in just two hits which led to some frustration with unlucky hits at the ends of long fights.There's an arcade mode similar to the mercenaries modes in Resident Evil that's pretty fun, assuming you like the combat. And that's really what American Nightmare boils down to, did you like the combat in Alan Wake? If so, this is for you, but don't come looking for the atmosphere or story of the original.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												Alan Wake's American Nightmare follows the adventures of Alan Wake as he attempts to chase down and thwart the schemes of his mysterious double by rewriting reality. As interesting as this may sound, the premise is ultimately let down by shallow combat and uninspired environments. In a story which seems so incredibly bizarre at first glance, it is a shame that the game which surrounds it is so average.Alan Wake's American Nightmare markets itself as a third person horror game, but fails to differentiate its self from other games in its genre. It's combat, While not bad, will seem very familiar to anyone who has spent any amount of time playing similar games. Ammo is plentiful and combat is relatively easy as a result. Most of the weapons available feel familiar as well, with basic pistols, rifles and shotguns making up the bulk of your arsenal. Only the occasional power tool manages to change up the stagnant weapon variety, but such weapons are too few and far between. Another minor way in which Alan Wake's American Nightmare tries to differentiate itself from its peers is through its use of the flashlight. Before an enemy will be vulnerable to attacks, they must be exposed to light for a period of time, either with a flashlight or other means. This creates some welcome tension, as the player tries to juggle foes with their flashlight, all while watching their batteries slowly drain. Unfortunately, doing so can become cumbersome in later sections of the game as the quantity of enemies being thrown at the player increases.I was also alarmed to discover that despite Alan Wake's American Nightmare's short length, it still managed to recycle most of it's environments multiple times. I don't believe that recycling environments is always a bad thing as long as they are sufficiently altered to create new and unique game-play experiences, but in this case I just felt as though the recycled spaces were their to serve as padding.While by no means a terrible game, Alan Wake's American Nightmare feels far too familiar. Throughout the experience I couldn't help but feel that my time would be better spent elsewhere. For people who are interested it may still be worth giving a shot, but don't expect anything amazing.

												This game had some really good ideas. A flashlight that recharges faster, and more streamlined weapons, ammo and dodge mechanics. However, the problem with the game is that it recycles the same some 3-4 stages over and over and over again. Once you think you beat the Arizona areas, the game puts you right back at the beginning of stage one all over again saying that something else has happened there. This is a cheap way to increase game time and easily becomes boring as very few to no new elements get introduced after this point, you are literally put in a loop. It might be that this is the game's vision but this pretentious ideology only saves the creators the time of actually creating more good ideas and locations that would make the story actually interesting.  I lament this fact because the game has really good functionality that is better in the first game, but throws it all away by literally reusing the same locations over and over and over again. DO NOT buy this game, instead, if you haven't already buy the first Alan Wake game instead.

Short version: 31%Alan Wake’s American Nightmare takes the best parts of the original game (the atmosphere, the setting, the mystery, and the cast) and throws it out completely; then takes the worst part of it (the combat mechanics, which are only enjoyable against a small group of enemies) and builds a whole game around it. The end product is a shallow, outrageous mockery of the original game, which may only be enjoyable for those who like the simplest B-grade shooter titles, or just thought that Alan Wake wasn’t like Max Payne enough.Long version:If Alan Wake was the video game equivalent of a large-budget mystery thriller miniseries that aired on prime time, then Alan Wake’s American Nightmare is like as if Syfy made the second season.The original game featured a highly detailed and lush environments and led you through several unique and enjoyable levels. This one has three painfully empty maps with a few objects scattered here and there and buildings crammed together with little coherence. And the maps are recycled three times in the so-called “story” with the exact same objectives, but with some new type of enemies.You can also forget the memorable supporting cast, here you have the most clichéd evil twin of the protagonist and three female supports, who are so bland and void of all character traits that you will most likely forget their names by the time you see the level end screen.In some manner this is all explained in the intro and in the (horribly banal) narrative: the whole story is supposed to be taken as some low-budget late-night horror show with all the bad things it comes with. But the problem is: they nailed it too perfectly. It is boring and uninteresting, and in all the wrong ways.And this leads us to the worst part of the game: it’s nothing, but a huge shooter. The weak story and the non-existent characters are only cardboard decoration to the never-ending shooting. The combat focus becomes even more painfully obvious when you see the Arcade mode in the main menu, which is exactly what it sounds like: you get dropped in an arena and must kill the never-ending wave of enemies.The only problem is: the mechanic is the same. You still have to shine light on them for several seconds to make them vulnerable, and you still can’t shoot while doing it. So each fight is nothing but a big chase around the empty maps: you try to dissolve shields while dozens of baddies are trying to get you. Sounds fun? Probably not, because it isn’t. Just avoid it and act like Alan Wake’s story ended with the last chapter of the original game.

Short version: 31%Alan Wake’s American Nightmare takes the best parts of the original game (the atmosphere, the setting, the mystery, and the cast) and throws it out completely; then takes the worst part of it (the combat mechanics, which are only enjoyable against a small group of enemies) and builds a whole game around it. The end product is a shallow, outrageous mockery of the original game, which may only be enjoyable for those who like the simplest B-grade shooter titles, or just thought that Alan Wake wasn’t like Max Payne enough.Long version:If Alan Wake was the video game equivalent of a large-budget mystery thriller miniseries that aired on prime time, then Alan Wake’s American Nightmare is like as if Syfy made the second season.The original game featured a highly detailed and lush environments and led you through several unique and enjoyable levels. This one has three painfully empty maps with a few objects scattered here and there and buildings crammed together with little coherence. And the maps are recycled three times in the so-called “story” with the exact same objectives, but with some new type of enemies.You can also forget the memorable supporting cast, here you have the most clichéd evil twin of the protagonist and three female supports, who are so bland and void of all character traits that you will most likely forget their names by the time you see the level end screen.In some manner this is all explained in the intro and in the (horribly banal) narrative: the whole story is supposed to be taken as some low-budget late-night horror show with all the bad things it comes with. But the problem is: they nailed it too perfectly. It is boring and uninteresting, and in all the wrong ways.And this leads us to the worst part of the game: it’s nothing, but a huge shooter. The weak story and the non-existent characters are only cardboard decoration to the never-ending shooting. The combat focus becomes even more painfully obvious when you see the Arcade mode in the main menu, which is exactly what it sounds like: you get dropped in an arena and must kill the never-ending wave of enemies.The only problem is: the mechanic is the same. You still have to shine light on them for several seconds to make them vulnerable, and you still can’t shoot while doing it. So each fight is nothing but a big chase around the empty maps: you try to dissolve shields while dozens of baddies are trying to get you. Sounds fun? Probably not, because it isn’t. Just avoid it and act like Alan Wake’s story ended with the last chapter of the original game.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2013
												Alan Wake's American Nightmare is one of the most atmospheric and immersive video games I've ever played. The story is a dark, twisted, sinister-like fantasy all wrapped up in a strong narrative by yours truly, The Champion of Light, Alan Wake.To tell you a little bit about the developer, Remedy, they brought us the classic video games like Max Payne 1 and 2. Inventive storytelling, with a dark tonality. Alan Wake's American Nightmare might not pose any scares like the original Alan Wake, but it's such a well-polished PC port that I can't help but acknowledge Remedy for doing such a wonderful job. The graphics feature high-resolution, and high-res textures, making the Xbox 360 version pale in comparison. I remember vividly playing the original Alan Wake on the Xbox 360 and the difference is like night and day. Although, I have no regrets about buying the original Alan Wake on the Xbox 360 because it went towards supporting such a great developer, and now we have American Nightmare. The visuals are clean and crisp. I think I took over 100 screenshots in my first 2-3 hours of gameplay. I couldn't help but stop to look at the surroundings and environments. The lighting and shadows are incredible. It's a beautiful game.Excellent story, narrative, atmosphere, immersion, and being one of the top 10 best PC-ported video games on the planet, American Nightmare stretches to a 6-7 hour standalone game for a mere price of $5-10 on a good sale. It's totally worth that much and more. Despite these bright features, American Nightmare is flawed by being too easy on the difficulty side. The game loses all tension on Normal mode, and it is best played on Nightmare mode instead. On Normal mode, there are ample ammo and weapons throughout the environments and fighting enemies is way too simplified and easy. Enemies do not even get close to you with the high amount of arsenal and flares at your disposal. But if you're just looking for an atmospheric experience without the challenge, then Normal mode is perfectly suitable for a playthrough.If you thoroughly enjoyed the original Alan Wake, and you want more of pursue more of the atmospheric-story-driven game, look no further. Turn the lights off, put on your headphones, and drift away into the darkness.Rating: 8 out of 10

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												As a writer, I consider the first Alan Wake a great game for its metalinguistic. The story within the story, the topic of what makes a writer a writer, the symbolism of the dark force as the market and the stupid corporate suits who twist and turn the will of an artist to make raw money... The fact that the story unfolded in two fronts (the game and the pages you collected) was specially fascinating.As a gamer, the first Alan wake was interesting, nothing special beyond the light mechanic but fun on its own way, I ended up annoyed because even in the nightmare, the enemies were merely annoying and there was too much ammo (and with my hoarder mentality from games like Resident Evil and Dead Space, I ended having lots of moments where I left crates of ammo behind because I was full).But this... unfortunately... feels like a shoddy and lazy filler. There is no story, it's just Alan hunting his doppleganger that it's in his place because story reasons that aren't really explained, the same places are used over and over and over. The city that the developers made with care to look alive and real is replaced by three patches of boring desert with three female characters that are awfully and lazily voiced. The combat has been dumbed down (amazingly), even if there are more guns for you to use, you can only carry two: A main arm, and a sidearm."But sir! Alan Wake was supposed to be realistic! The devs said so! You don't see a guy carrying fifteen weapons on his pockets!" Yeah, the devs also said that this game is more action-packed and inspired in americana action series. It's specially grieving since now ammo is universal. Black and red boxes will fill ammo for your side arm, and orange boxes will give ammo for your main weapon. Regardless if you're using an uzi, a nail gun, a rifle or a shotgun. It mostly boils to the fact that they wanted to port it from the consoles to the computers as fast as they could and couldn't be bothered with changing.And to make things 'worse', the 'realistic' excuse can't be used anymore, since Alan now fights weird enemies that turn into birds or that split in half when shown bright light. While in the first game the dark presence merely took possession of people and objects, now it... mutates them? It gives an excuse that since the antagonist is different, it does different stuff but... again, within the own meta-linguistic, the story gives no reason WHY the antagonist could do it.Speaking of meta-linguistic, all the pages that explained what happened to npcs and about the story that is unfolding were, again, severely dumbed down. With only three girls to talk to and three scenarios, and with most of the surprises being gone, most pages are just filler, annoying filler, needless filler.While I didn't had high expectations about this game (with the company acknowledging that they wanted their time to make Alan Wake 2 and didn't wanted to rush things) I at least expected that they would do an enjoyable work, like the DLCs from the first game.The only way I could reccomend this game is if you liked the combat mechanics from the first Alan Wake and wanted to play a dumbed down, arcade version of it.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2013
												American Nightmare represents an epilogue to the main Alan Wake game, and as such it would be best to complete that story first.  Alan finds himself "stuck" in a new reality taunted by his evil doppleganger, whom he must eventually destroy to escape back to his wife in the "normal" world... where 2 years have passed and everyone believes Alan dead.  Again-another great idea, but the execution feels quite tedious.  The world is more open now and there is a map to guide you to your objectives.  the action mechanic of stunning and shooting the Taken is still present, although ammo and weapons are plentiful... I did not die once during the game on Normal.  There are manuscript pages, TVs, and radio shows to absorb if you have the patience to do so.  What killed it for me was the fact that you complete the same 3 maps and objectives 3 times!!  Granted, each time the tasks are attenuated a bit, but there is nothing new to discover with subsequent iterations.  Bargain bin please.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2013
												First off, let me just say this: This game has no effect on the Alan Wake universe.  All the game reveals is that Mr. Scratch is a bad guy.Now, onto the review.This game fleshes out new ideas in case Alan Wake 2 would come out.  For example, there are some new monsters such as a spider-parasite thing, a monster that morphs into two when light is shined on it, one guy who can change from ravens to a man, and finally a guy who throws dark grenades at you.There are also some new weapons, such as the nailgun, the machine guns, and probably some other stuff I don't remember.For 15$, this game is not worth buying.  The story mode is unique at first, but then it gets repetitive.  In short, this game makes you repeat the exact same story three times in a row before you beat it.  Yup, that's right.  You do the same things thrice, and then you beat the story mode.  If you want to buy this game for the story mode, pass on it.The reason anyone would want to buy this game is for the arcade mode.  It is a 10-minute fight with waves of Taken.  This is unusually easy in this version because the weapons are so much more powerful and because the flashlight recharges almost instantly, rendering batteries near useless.TL;DRDon't buy it if you are looking for a good story.  Buy it on sale for the arcade if that's what you want to play.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												Presenting itself as an episode of a Twilight Zone-esque television show called "Night Springs," complete with a Rod Serling soundalike narrator, Alan Wake's American Nightmare sees the titular hero facing off against an evil manifestation of himself, called Mr. Scratch. Scratch has taken up residence in a small Arizona town, and has turned most of the population into zombie-like hostiles called "the taken." Much of Alan Wake's American Nightmare's gameplay involves dealing with the taken, who attack Wake at regular intervals. The taken are usually protected by a cloak of shadows, which must be "burned" away using Wake's flashlight beam before he can then employ firearms to permanently put them on the other side of the dirt. Dodging enemy melee attacks is a heavily emphasized element of the gameplay: successfully doing it both slows down time and lets Wake get some distance from bad guys.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												Alan Wake's American Nightmare is a disappointing spin-off title that feels more like a new episode for the original game than a proper sequel. At least the engine has been upgraded and the controls and visuals are certainly better. This is a good thing too, since American Nightmare is a much more action-oriented game.Unfortunately in most other ways American Nightmare is an inferior product. It does not have any of the original's atmosphere or tension, the story is rather messy and the game is also quite short. Additionally, there's only three small maps and they are all revisited during the campaign.It's not a bad game as such, just rather disappointing after the strong original game. Only recommended for big fans of the original or during a sale.The good:- Nice visuals- Improved controls- Several new enemy typesThe bad:- Weak story- Rather short- Lacks the atmosphere of the original- Only three small maps that are all revisited several times- Poorly written side characters who don't really seem to fit in Alan Wake's world- Ammo refills are everywhere and there's no challenge anymore on normal

Posted: December 24, 2015
												If I was enthusiastic about Alan Wake, the second opus American Nightmare is a major disappointment. First of all, the game is mostly a shooter. You basically start with some arsenal, and get more powerful weapon as you go. Plus, there are boxes with ammuntion that auto-refills, thus loosing the pressure of  trying to get out the shooting as much as you can. Alan Wake turned badass is a bad idea.Second, the game features only 3 maps, with the same characters and the same puzzles that you will play to death thanks to a time loop. Yep. The first time when you go back at your starting point, you ask yourself what you did wrong. Then the second time, you feel the game is just playing with you nerves and just want to finish it as soon as possible and forget it.Really, Alan Wake's American Nightmare should be played only to see how an otherwise great licence can crash and burn due to unwise design choice.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												As far as games go, this one is satisfying enough to play if you're interested in only the game mechanics. The guns feel varied and responsive, it's challenging, and a solid enough shooter. Where this game lacks, is story. It truly feels incomplete, the characters are all cardboard, unappealing representations of women (BOOOORIIIING), to the point where how terrible they are is almost offensive. Unlike with Alan Wake, there's no sense of accomplishment from beating this game. While Alan Wake didn't have what I'd call a true boss battle to begin with, there was a definite endurance run that had some challenge to it. Alan Wake's American Nightmare is repetitive, uninteresting, unsatisfying, and as far as a story or complete game feeling, a total let down. It does not live up to the bar set by its predecessor. A fun shooter, lacking the substance and character of the first game. It's like I could see where there was SUPPOSED to be a game, but they didn't quite make it there or finish it. So... Meh?

content:
Posted: January 10
												So I'll keep this simple and short. This game costs less than the original Alan Wake. The reason for this is that Alan Wake was a full game and this one, Alan Wake: The American Nightmare, was an Xbox Live Arcade game. That being said, if you heard of this game somewhere, or want to give it a try just go and play the first one for two simple reasons. 1) Alan Wake: The American Nightmare is a sequel. 2) Original Alan Wake is much better in every way.I'll keep this short. If you play The American Nightmare first, you won't like Alan Wake and miss all the answers for "What, who, where, how and why". Alan Wake is a great game, however this sequel was made purely to create a game where you could fully experience the unique Alan Wake combat mechanic. Alan Wake: The American Nightmare is short, less of a horror, more of a shooter than the original one. However, it's a good sequel in regards of "STORY". Alan Wake fans should play this game as it's not a spin off or side story but a straight out sequel.

												This game is decent but nothing I myself would rave about. I played the first Alan Wake and remember they combat and weapons and story. This game is good with graphics and is a solid familiar feel to the old version but certainly isn't as pleasing. This game features more weapons which i believe is one of the greatest downfalls of the game. I mean the reward of collecting pages for a better weapon is okay but i believe could of been integrated in a different way.  This game was way to easy to complete and the mechanics babied you too much the entire time. On my first playthrough i beat the game in 3.5 hours and collected 40 out of the 53 pages. The mini map even had minor indicators for the pages you search for; which tells me that the pages truely aren't hidden. Your suppose to work for the pages not be lead to them. With this said the unlockable weapons will range from a scale of VERY underpowered or SUPER overpowered. To me the characters are crap for realism. Alan wake is a Writer not a soldier and somehow he knows how to perfectly use an assault rifle? The character even admits it himself in the first game he never used a gun for a long period of time if at all. The mechanics of the revolvers, shotguns and a bolt action rifle are easy to learn by looking at them. But military grade weapons are much to complex to use like a pro the first shot. With this said your magical ability to use each weapon like a master and reload them withen seconds is what makes the game far too easy. The story was meh but good if you get it on sale for a time killer. i paid 99cents .  I say content was extremely lacking and this game feels more like a special dlc for the game.  I say this game is worth one playthrough if your a fan of Alan wake but other then that this game is definitely not worth full price. wait for a holiday sale . With all this said i must add that the first game had a stronger feel of lonely helplessness while here you feel like your able to fully help yourself with no big issue. but would i reccomend this that would be a no.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Alan Wake's American Nightmare is essentially an all action (similar to Resident Evil) 'sort-of' continuation of the original Alan Wake storyline. It follows the "stuck in nightmare world" idea, and most of your time is spent blasting away enemies in (the same) three stages. Repeat that three times and that's all there is to American Nightmare. Not much.American Nightmare completely lacks the psychological aspect of 'psychological thriller,' that the original Alan Wake was barely able to pull off (similar to Silent Hill). Besides sharing the same name, the two titles have little in common. American Nightmare is simply Alan Wake, reduced to a basic shoot-em-up arcade style games with little-to-no story set in three repeated stages.Also worth mentioning is that if you're looking for some resolution to the ending of the original Alan Wake, you won't find it here.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												I am an absolutely massive fan of Alan Wake; it's one of my favourite games of all time, I've finished it countless times on the Xbox 360, and I have a blast every time I play it. With that said, I found this standalone sequel to be rather disappointing in comparison to the brilliant first game; bear in mind that I do not think this is a bad game, it just falls rather falt and disappoints after the first game.Alan Wake's American Nightmare is intended to play out as an episode of the fictional TV show called Night Springs, and is narrated by Lloyd Floyd, who provides an interesting narration to the story.The game has Alan Wake trapped in a sparse desert area, and who must find a way to escape the recurring nightmare he is stuck in.And that leads to my first problem with the game; because Alan is stuck in a nightmare which repeats itself, you are forced to endure the same hour of gameplay THREE TIMES in a row until you finish this game. The exact same missions and locations, repeated three times. The first time is fun, the second time is kinda uninteresting, and the third time is downright boring and repetitive. This is a lazy way to repeat locations in a game, and it also reflects the poor writing skill of the writers. The story is rather weird and disjointed. Throughout the entire game, you do a lot of things for unexplained reasons which aren't apparrently clear when you do them or even at the end of the game. The whole story is weird and quirky, but not in a good way, as it barely makes sense. The characters, apart from Alan and the absolutely BRILLIANT Mr Scratch, are boring and are just as quirky as the story itself. However, I found the live action cut scenes rather good, which was a surprise for me.The gameplay is exactly the same as the first game, except that you can use new weapons like sub machine guns and nail guns. That's it. Zero changes made to the gameplay.There's also a survival mode, which is actually quite fun. It's intense, challenging, and a fun way to compete on the leaderboards with your friends. I found this mode better than the campaign to be honest.Overall, this is certainly not a bad game; it merely fails to innovate, and doesn't capture me the way the first game did. I still love Alan Wake, but this game disappointed me quite a bit. If you don't mind an extremely repetitive story, even with the game's shining parts, then pick t up for $3 on sale. 6 / 10.

												Alan Wake:American Nightmare is a spin-off to original game.You play as Alan Wake who is a writer and you must fight your way through darkness using light and firearms. While it’s not a direct sequel to previous game it still has same mechanics. But this time Remedy added more weapons making game more intense. While the main story is only 4 hours long it lacks good plot, and memorable characters. You just simply travel to 3 “Areas” 3 times and fight dark creatures to find some special objects to complete your mission in exact area. The atmosphere is great. It has gloomy backgrounds of Arizona which makes it look cool. Very awesome soundtrack to listen. You can also search for hidden manuscripts scattered all over the world which can be read later. It’s basically “Horde Mode” just to kill waves of enemies till the dawn across 5 different maps.7/10

												A brilliant stand-alone experience/ dlc. Prepare to face off against the ultimate american nightmare with a flashlight and a couple of bullets. Drastically more action packed than Alan Wake, this game generously provides you with an upgrade in firepower. Assault rifles, pump action shotguns, uzi machine pistols, all at your disposal to use however you like. You are also provided with flares and flash-bangs for when things get a little TOO tight. content:
Posted: December 18, 2012
												I actually liked this more than the regular campaign. This is kind of like a mix between the main campaign and a really basic open-world game. It's a lot more open than the main campaign, but it's still rather linear, in that there is only ever one objective that can be done at a time, but you can roam around and explore. The areas aren't very big, and you can't freely travel between them, but this kind of gives me a taste of what the main campaign could have been like if it were designed as an open world game instead of being as utterly claustrophobic as it was.This standalone DLC made quite a few changes from the original game, but not all of them were good. In the original Alan Wake, there were 4 weapons. In this one, there are 2 pistols, 2 rifles, 3 shotguns, 2 automatic weapons, a flaregun, and a nailgun. While choice is always good, some of the weapons are insanely overpowered, and some are just pointless. It seems like the developers took people's complaints about the main game's combat system to mean that combat was too difficult (it wasn't), and made it easier. Unfortunately, that means combat is now a cakewalk. Ammo is RIDICULOUSLY plentiful, weapons are insanely powerful, and enemies will barely ever even get close enough to hit you. Throughout the whole game, I got hit maybe 4 times, used 1 handheld flare, never fired the flaregun, and totally forgot I even HAD flashbangs.They beefed up the flashlight as well. The enemies seem like they take less light to burn away the darkness, and the flashlight recharges CRAZY fast. From completely empty, it will charge to full in about 3 seconds, including the 1-2 second delay before it even starts charging. I was playing on Normal (there's only normal and nightmare), too, but maybe in this game that's the equivalent of easy.The story is still rather interesting in this expansion, but the writing and voice acting are HORRIBLE. I mean absurdly stupid at times. I'm all for campy fun, but sometimes it gets so ridiculous that it really pulls you out of the experience. Speaking of acting, the little "TV" segments where your dark self talks to you go on WAY too long sometimes, and don't really play any importance in how the game unfolds (and you don't get any achievements for them or anything).Overall I liked this. The story and acting took a step backwards from the main game, but you're not confined to the stupid outdoor tunnel sections (running through the woods), and combat doesn't get in your way as horrifically as it did in the main game either.It's rather short, so don't pay $20 for it or anything, but I enjoyed it. Your results may vary, of course.

												Well... It's worth the money in a sale for a quick play but honestly... This game has nothing on the original game.  Very quickly it stands out that the main game mechanic which made this series unique has been tampered with and spoiled... The mechanic I am talking about is light.  Light is the key to defeating the darkness, and no idea lightbulbs went off in the developers heads that made this.The First game had little weapons, and had multiple flashlight types, beyond your regular flashlight you could find a heavy duty flashlight and two lantern type lights that in a world of combating darkness was amazing... this game replaces atmosphere and light combat with dumbed down boring gun fighting, many weapons are now available such as an Uzi and M16 and to be blunt... they just dont fit.  The normal light from the flashlight no longer burns away dark... it simply does nothing, you must focus the flashlight to make it do anything... mostly it's just a case of focus light, spray uzi or M16 and repeat now this... is the ultimate sin... They basicly ruined the main combat mechanic that made this game special and replaced it with bland generic shooting.There are only three areas in this game, and those get reused several times as a time loop plot device... the ever repeating events become dull and the newer enemys just don't make it interesting enough to make it enjoyable...  infact the other characters remembering the previous loops ahve having previous tasks already finished only highlights the boredom the developers must have realised would happen playing the same content over and over again.The first game was dark... VERY dark and the dark fog and shimmering enemys gave me goose bumps... this game did nothing to make me feel dark was dangerous or intimidating, there was no eerie fog everywhere and no sense of dread that made you wish for teh next brightly lit area to come soon... the game just wasn't creapy, spooky, or scary... it just didn't do a good job at all.The sandbox arcade mode where you fight till dawn is a fun addition, and it is fun to try and beat your friends scores and try to survive for the full 10 minutes untill dawn... actually that is almost the only time this game seems to remember that light is your ally...So as I mentioned...   The game is worth a play as a sale price... it's just nowhere near as good as the first game.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												HOUR COUNT: >20 on Xbox 360, 1.5 on PCTL;DR: A nice little Xbox Live Arcade game, but not quite as good as the original game.  Also, it's a little short.  Arcade mode can add a lot of replayability.  If you're not sure, just pick it up on sale, preferrably as the Alan Wake Franchise so you can get the amazing first title.--Do I recommend it?  Only if you liked the first, or want the arcade mode.  Still rocking those fight-with-light mechanics, still fighting them darkness zambies, just more of the same-- which, trust me, isn't a bad thing!  It's a four to six hour standalone DLC campaign taking place after the events of the first game, and possibly the closest we'll ever get to a sequel (since Remedy's in deep♥♥♥♥♥♥and leaning on the success of Quantum Break).I went ahead and took the game for a spin in arcade mode, and the port is excellent.  Easy 60 FPS with very few dips to 48 while maxed out at 1360x768, R9 280 and Pentium E6600 with 4GB of RAM.  32-bit users welcome.  Much less CPU-intensive than the original game, and much more optimized for 60 FPS.  Vsync can cause a few strange issues with mouse sensitivity, though.The DLC campaign has about two hours of fresh new levels, then goes back to repeat itself three times.  Don't worry; you only cross over some of the centerpieces of each level, and you keep getting exposed to new parts of the levels you haven't visited before.  It's definitely a good campaign, and while it isn't on par with the original (as very few games are), it'll keep you playing for the duration.Mechanically, it's good ol' Alan Wake.  The only change is that you can't just aim at them to burn their shields away.  This time, you HAVE to be boosting your flashlight (right-click) to wear down their shields... which makes combat a little more tense, since your magical shieldbreaker now has limited ammunition.  The dodging mechanic also seems to be a little more responsive, and enemies don't throw♥♥♥♥♥♥at you nearly as much.Arcade mode was done well, though it could be better.  You start with a 9mm and flashlight, you have an ammo box that comes back every three minutes, a few lights to replenish your health, and you've got 10 minutes until sunrise.  There's also weapons around the map, and a few weapon cases that can only be opened if you collected x number of manuscript pages during the campaign.  You get tons of enemies thrown at you with several variations, and you need to get the highest score you can by avoiding damage and taking out enemies.  Get a high enough rating, and you can unlock the next mission.  There's 5 or 6 stages, and a Nightmare variation (more enemies, constant spawning instead of wave-based) for each.Is it worth $15?  Yes, but it's not the best game out there.  My recommendation's to save up and buy the Alan Wake Franchise bundle, so you can get both titles.  If in doubt, wait for a Steam sale.

Posted: June 7, 2014
												Isn't it just the worst when you expect a game to be good and it isn't?The original Alan Wake was a game centered on the titular suspense/horror author, as he fought againt the forces of darkness in a sleepy little mountain town, saving his wife and the day in an episodic fashion, to the point that there were credits at the end of each chapter along with "next time" and "last time" intros and outros. It was a neat story, and a neat idea, and the combat was something out of the ordinary. Seems like it wouldn't be hard to follow up, right?American Nightmare almost seems like a demo for the whole game. The conciet of the plot in this iteration is that our hero is caught in a time loop, but effectively what this translates to is that you go through the same 3 small areas 3 times. There are no "episodes", there is no getting from point A to point B, you simply "win" the particular scene by progressing the story along, and are immediately greeted with a loading screen, taking you straight to the next area. Meanwhile the combat, while interesting in the first game, has not changed at all in this second, and every single enemy can be taken down the exact same way. Shine the light, shoot bullets. A little added variety would have done a bit to save it, but not much.Additionally, the story itself seems a bit muddied and vague, although given how much space they gave themselves to work with, it's surprising they managed to convey a cohesive story in such a small span of game. The badguy is bad, the good guy is good, he wins, and everything is fine. The credits then tell us that we haven't seen the last of Mr. Wake, but for the audience's sake, I hope Alan has brushed up on his writing skills."I found this game shallow and pedantic."-Peter Griffin

												A follow-up to Alan Wake, "American Nightmare" fleshes out themes only touched on in the original. The plot is a little bit more straightforward this time around, but still leaves that feeling that you have only seen part of the bigger picture. A truly nasty antagonist, improvements to the combat engine, and an overall lighter tone, go a long way to make this game feel like a completely viable chapter in the Alan Wake storyline. Posted: January 2, 2014
												American Nightmare is a stand alone expansion to Alan Wake from Remedy Entertainment. Originally an Xbox live title this has made its way over to the PC with a few tweaks. Graphics are not powerhouse hungry but its not going to make you vomit in disgust at its admitadly bland pallet. As this game is set mostly in the desert with minimal indoor environmets this game is no stranger to the colour brown. The PC version does look better than its console sibling with AA options and a HD texture pack.The gameplay is very similar to the main game with a familar over the shoulder third person camera with a reasonable FOV. Ok its a very console orientated FOV and this game does play better with a gamepad than a keyboard and mouse although you want cry and bang your head on the desk if you dont have a gamepad. So I would recommend plugging in a pad and scooting your chair back a tad for a more comforatable experience. The weapons have a nice feel to them, the traditional pistol, rifle and shotgun are back with interesting additions such as the nail gun. There is enough variety of weapons around and plenty of ammo to keep gameplay fresh. The flashlight returns to burn off the "Darkness" which acts as a shield to enemies making them imune to bullets. But like in the main game the enemies are vunerable to all forms of lights, whether this is car headlights, flares or the sun.The game lets face it is not very long. The story mode takes about 3/4 hours to complete but considering this started out as an xbox live arcade expansion this is not a bad thing. Especially when the game costs less than a pint. New to American Nightmare is an arcade mode. This is basically a horde mode escape the zombies make it till dawn affair. It has a couple of achievements and map unlocks but single player means its not something you are going to come back to.So should you buy it? Have you played Alan Wake? If not go pick that up. Its not expensive, has a great story in the style of Stephen King novels. This game is a bit of an oddball rounding off the story that a lot of people expected from the main game. If you have played the base game, then deffinately pick this up. Although a little repeptive in the story it provides a better finish to the story you got so into in the previous incarnation.

Posted: April 16, 2014
												Alan Wake's American Nightmare is something of a sequel to the original Alan Wake. From what I understand it's the continuation of the story and was intended to be either released episodically or as a stop gap between the first and second game. Sadly there isn't any news on a second game coming so far, beyond the 'to be continued' that you get at the end credits.Anyway, the game itself is pretty good. It hasn't lost any of the voice acting or nice little bits. The Alan Wake series is one of the few games that actually makes me want to collect the collectibles,, which in this cases are manuscript pages that can be read. Each page reveals more of the world so The player can understand the world more.This title is a lot more combat orientated that the original with more varied enemies and tougher ones at that. Not to worry though your arsenal can be upgraded through weapons cases that are unlocked by finding the aforementioned collectibles. 3 gets you an smg, 10 a magnum and so on.I'd recommend this game, it's actually worth it's asking price, though replayability is low. There is a arcade mode that can make the game last a bit longer. Be aware that you really do need to like plot heavy games to really enjoy this title.

												It's hard to recommend this title. In a way it started out as a nice, albeit quite cheesy, video game based off of the original. The narrative, one of the best things of the previous title, is extremely silly. A complete joke compared to the original. The game has you explore a handful of regions three times in a row, explained in the story as some kind of time cycle or trial-and-error run as Alan Wake tries to re-write his story. As far as gameplay is concerned, it means you'll spend doing roughly the same stuff over and over again and simply feels lazy on the part of the developers. The areas are okay, certainly not as atmospheric as the Pacific North West of the original. The game is considerably short as well, clocking in at three hours at most (I've finished my run in 2.5 hours). As short as it is, the game actually starts to drag halfway through since there isn't any new in terms of scenery. Gameplay-wise, however, it is as solid as the previous title. The enemies are diverse and the gunplay, mixed with the light mechanic, still feels as fresh as in the original. Ammunition is less scarce so the survival aspect that was present in the original is gone (safe havens are also more frequent), though this isn't all too bad. As a standalone it is hard to recommend, though I guess it should be seen as more of an expansion or perhaps (standalone) DLC. Taking the price-tag into account, I'm giving the game the benefit of the doubt. I feel the gameplay is enough to carry it.Bottom line is that it is a fun game to kill an evening, but don't expect this to be "Alan Wake 2".

Posted: September 8, 2014
												Alan Wake’s American Nightmare is a third person shooter in the psychological horror genre.  It is a stand-alone DLC that continues the story of the original Alan Wake game.You play as Alan again fighting against his evil alter-ego and his minions of darkness.  He still wields up to six weapons – 1-hand gun, 2-hand gun, flare gun, flares, flashbang grenades and, most crucial, a flashlight.  The flashlight is required to remove the enemy shields in order to make them vulnerable to your guns.  Ammo (and batteries for your flashlight) are everywhere and there are quite a few more guns to choose from.The story this time around pits you against your doppelganger, created by the Dark Presence.  There are some new interesting variations on the minions you face which helps against monotony.   What doesn’t help is that the three zones that the story takes you through get re-used three times each, creating nine areas to complete the game.  They do their creative best to make things a little different each time through, but there is no way to hide the inevitable repetition.The graphics have been slightly updated from the original.  There are some great cutscenes and the voice acting is still superb.  The real life actor playing Alan Wake has some choice scenes playing the evil twin and taunting Alan through videos you can play on various TV sets.They have toned down the many collectibles from the first game.  There are 50+ manuscript pages to find and these provide story exposition and are required to unlock better weapons.  Likewise, there are only 12 achievements now and half are associated with the new Arcade Mode.  Arcade Mode removes the storyline completely and allows the player to try and survive the night in different maps against waves of enemies.  You can compare your scores against your friends….still no co-op or multi-player available.American Nightmare’s Story Mode can easily be completed in less than five hours, although the Arcade Mode can provide some additional hours of fun.  Overall, worth playing if you wait for the right Steam sale.
