Posted: December 13, 2015
												*This review will contain some spoilers for the story of Alan Wake, as well as some gameplay spoilers for American Nightmare. Read at your own disgression!* Alan Wake´s American Nightmare is a spinoff-title to the original Alan Wake. While it shares a lot of similarities with its predecessor, there is a notable amount of changes and new stuff that one should be aware before considering playing it, as these changes and additions will decide whether this game works for you or not.The story takes place within an episode of the TV show "Night Springs" (basically the Twilight Zone of Videogames). Alan, still trapped within the Darkness of the Lake after the end of the first game (and its DLC, to be more precise), has now been trapped within one of his own stories, by none other than his doppelgänger, Mr. Scratch. Caught in a loop of endless repetition and constant torment by Scratch, Alan has to find a way to "break the circle" and return to the real world before his doppelgänger has completely overtaken his "real" life.The gameplay of American Nightmare, at first glance, is basically the same as it was in Alan Wake: You run around in comparatively small, open areas, defeat Taken, collect manuscript pages to fill in story details, and solve some (very easy) puzzles or try and reach a certain spot to advance the story, while occacionally watching TV, listening to the radio and talking to a handful of people. This all takes place on three maps: A Gas Station/Motel in the middle of the Arizonian Desert, an Observatory, and a Drive-in Theater. While each map is quite distinct from the others, you also have to revisit each map several times over the course of the game. While this is explained and justified quite well within the story, this still means that two-thirds of the campaign are repeated content (minor changes notwithstanding). Thankfully, the actual gameplay is good enough so that one can look past it.American Nightmare, gameplay-wise, improves on both Alan Wake´s enemy design and weapon selection. While the regular Taken are still the bread-and-butter of your combat enemies, there are also various new enemy types that demand some different strategies from the usual "shine your light on them, destroy their shield, and then shoot them". This includes Taken that are immune to your flashlight and instead split into smaller versions of themselves, Taken that flee by transforming into bird flocks, and Taken that throw "Darkness Grenades" into your direction, but keep their distance, among other enemy types. To counter them, Alan now also has access to a much larger arsenal, which gets unlocked the more manuscript pages you collect, so even if you don´t care about the story at all, you should still keep your eyes open for them. The new arsenal includes pistols, a SMG, an Assault Rifle, a Combat Shotgun, a crossbow which ignores the enemy shield, and a Nailgun, among others. Some stuff from Alan Wake also makes a return, like the flaregun and the flashbangs, but they have become quite a bit weaker, no longer insta-killing anything, but rather destroying their shields quickly (which is still useful, of course).The gameplay in general is alot less "survival" and much more action-orientated. You will pretty much never run out of ammo or flashlight batteries, individual enemies are alot less threatening than they used to but appear in bigger numbers, and there is alot less general "creepiness" in wandering around the desert (though that may just be me). The game, in all fairness, also doesn´t try to be a horror game, unless you count the psychological "threat to your very existence, a doppelgänger overtaking your life" angle. In that regard, your occasional encounters with Mr. Scratch are fun, he´s quite a cool and fun, if decidedly hammy, villain, but there´s unfortunately no fight against him, or any boss fight at all, for that matter, which feels like a wasted opportunity, given the more arcade-y gameplay.Once you´re done with the campaign, there´s also an Arcade Mode, in which you have to survive a certain amount of time on various maps while fending off enemies, raising your combo meter (by killing enemies and evading their attacks) and getting enough points to earn stars and unlock new and more difficult maps. Its quite fun (and more difficult than the main campaign ever gets), but probably not something that you will play for more than a few hours.Overall, I personally would recommend American Nightmare, especially if it´s at a discount. If you liked Alan Wake overall, but disliked its gameplay, you will probably like it. If you didn´t like Alan Wake or aren´t interested in the franchise at all, I would still say that you should check it out, but the game will probably not change your overall opinion on the series.

You can also turn off the UI in American Nightmare, however the visual cues aren't as present.  Other than the story mode there is an arcade survival minigame that the first game lacks.The Not-So-Goods:  The game was lacking in real character develpment.  There was a time travel plot device that recycled all of the maps.  There is a character known as Mr. Scratch that is one of the worst additions to a sequel.  Overall sloppy story.  There is no real mention to Alice other than the end of the game.  The subtlety of the visuals in AW are not present in American Nightmare.  While the weapons are much more varied than AW, it feels like the nailgun for instance is just a rapid fire pistol with lacking damage.  You cannot drain the Taken's darkness from them by simply pointing their flashlight at it.  You must boost it as well.I give this game a 6/10 for its lacking story.  However, most of what makes AW great is present in this one.  The score is so low because the decisions Remedy made to the game are slightly sloppy.

Posted: May 23, 2012
												Episodic gaming is hardly a new concept. From Half-Life 2: Episode 1 to Sam & Max Save The World and SiN Episodes, there were many attempts at this format. Alan Wake's American Nightmare is different. Despite being a direct sequel to the original game, it is essentially a self-contained story with a beginning and a satisfying ending. In terms of quality, American Nightmare matches and occasionally surpasses the original. The combat has been improved (there is even an alternative aiming mode offered in the configurations menu); the improved overall feedback as well as the expanded arsenal and creative new foes make the 'fight with light' combat especially enjoyable. The story is the hightlight of American Nightmare, taking full advantage of the episodic format with its clever twist. The dialogue is snappy and frequently genuinely funny. The main antagonist, Mr. Scratch (or Mr. [...] if you prefer), is disturbing and hilarious, often both at once. I am running out of space here. Play it!

Posted: July 15, 2015
												A quirky side chapter/followup on the original Alan Wake, American Nightmare polishes the battle mechanics and sprinting, although they didn't touch the climbing (thankfully you do none or very little of it here). The game takes place within 3 distinct areas, has a few collectibles for which the franchise (I guess we can call it that now) is known for, and a great story, thought not as good as the original, it still serves to know what is transpiring after the end of AW. They also took note on the lack of enemy diversity and introduced a few new ones here as well.Now, there's also a very fun Arcade mode, a wave style battle arena, in which you have to battle hoards of Taken for 10 minutes until the sun rises and the battle ends. If you've played RE mercenaries, it's similar, although much simpler and not as hard. The levels come in two varieties: Normal Mode in which the enemies come in limited waves, and Nightmare Mode in which the enemies consistently keep spawning with no breaks between waves. It took me 12.5 hours to beat it 100%, it may take you less if you're skilled at wave-style arena games. It's rewardingly challenging but not too difficult to achieve, in my opinion.I highly recommend this game for its gameplay and story as well as its fun arcade mode; it's fully worth the price of admission, but perhaps you'll want to get it during a sale.

												How are people liking this!? I mean, it started out pretty decently... until the "game" stopped becoming a game. It is literally a huge, tedious collect-a- thon where you go through the same levels, doing the same stuff that you already did, over and over again. I get it, the whole "plot" is that (SPOILERS) Mr.Wake is stuck in a time loop and is trying to make things right so that he may finally put an end to all the crap happening. Okay, yeah... that's fitting and that's okay. However, it is not okay when your so called "game" consists of (like I've said before) going through the same thing, again and again. It was interesting the first time but now, it's just getting on my nerves. It's boring, repetitive (literally), and just down right unenjoyable to have to go through. It's clear, at least to me that the developers did not put much thought into this and they sure seem to have run out of ideas half way through making this. To make things even worse, there is no variety. They try to switch it up with the tasks but, it's obviously the same ones that you just did but, in a different order... seriously, that's it. However, that's not really the worst thing about this. I think that the worst thing about this so calle "game" is the fights and the enemies. Since when was it okay to surround the player with more than twenty enemies!? Or so, it seems. There are way too many enemies during a fight and to amp up the unfairness even further, they are stronger, faster, very resilliant to your flashlight (or any ligh for that matter), and just close to impossible to kill, dodge, or runaway from. By the time you're even able to pull up your gun, you're surrounded and are being beaten within an inch of your life. You'll be trying your hardest to break the darkness off of them and shoot them but of course, while you're in the middle of doing this, there will be multiple enemies allready surrounding you. Nevermind the fact that your flashlight charge barely lasts long enough to even break the darkness on one enemy! You only have enough charge to even do one enemy at a time which obviously, doesn't work and just slows you down. And then finally, it really does seem like not that much thought was given to the programming. What I mean is that, you'll out run the enemy and be more than safe distance away from him but, it doesn't matter because somehow, he can still hit you. Enemy attacks are also very diffivult to get out of and so, if you get hit even once, then you might as well give up becasue you'll just get stuck into an enemy's combo and killed instantly. There is so much more that I could probablty complain about here but, I've already taken up enough space and I just can't think of anything else at the moment. Besides, trying to think about this game at all is slightly infuriating me. That's the key word here, "infuriating".,, that's all this will ever be, so much to the point where I flat out quit playing.

Posted: January 3, 2016
												This is a direct sequel to the first game. It attempts to explain events directly after the conclusion of the first game and then takes place two years after the events in Bright Falls. To simplify without spoiling too much, Alan is in a sort of limbo ("The Dark Place"), and is desperately trying to get back to the real world (which has written him off for dead), his wife, his friends, and his job.However, the Dark Presence (the bad thing) has taken on Alan's skin and can travel to the real world; it is also actively keeping Alan stuck in the Dark Place while he attempts to ruin Alan's life in the real world by being a massive psychotic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (think serial killer / torturer). You have to get out of the Dark Place, kill the Dark Presence that is imitating you, and get back to life.The only problem is: The Dark Presence can send you back in time to repeat the same thing over and over again, so this experience becomes basically a very, very dark Groundhog Day. Each time you go through the time loop, the people you interact with remember bits and pieces of your last visit, so you slowly untangle the mess.This game is much more action-oriented than the first. There is no danger of running out of ammo, and there are lots more weapons (including heavy stuff like a combat shotgun, all kinds of rifles, automatic weapons, and even a sweet crossbow and nail gun). It's a lot more run-and-gun and much more satisfying in terms of killing bad guys.The story is just as convoluted as the first game, so if you liked the story of the first one, this is a great follow-up to the game. It's much shorter than the first game so it's a fun little 1-2 night wrap-up of the story.There's also an arcade mode with leaderboards where you just get to survive a certain number of waves of Taken while using ammo and weapons scattered around the level. Unlocking weapons in Story mode gets you better gear in Arcade mode.

												Episodic gaming is hardly a new concept. From Half-Life 2: Episode 1 to Sam & Max Save The World and SiN Episodes, there were many attempts at this format. Alan Wake's American Nightmare is different. Despite being a direct sequel to the original game, it is essentially a self-contained story with a beginning and a satisfying ending. In terms of quality, American Nightmare matches and occasionally surpasses the original. The combat has been improved (there is even an alternative aiming mode offered in the configurations menu); the improved overall feedback as well as the expanded arsenal and creative new foes make the 'fight with light' combat especially enjoyable. The story is the hightlight of American Nightmare, taking full advantage of the episodic format with its clever twist. The dialogue is snappy and frequently genuinely funny. The main antagonist, Mr. Scratch (or Mr. [...] if you prefer), is disturbing and hilarious, often both at once. I am running out of space here. Play it!

Posted: February 26, 2015
												A brief nightmare...Alan Wake's American Nightmare is a third person shooter developed by Remedy (Max Payne and Alan Wake creators). It is a standalone game, set in the 'Alan Wake' Universe. You play as Alan Wake, a writer who has gotten stuck in a television series called 'Night Springs'.The plot doesn't have a significant impact on the original story. Continuing (if somewhat loosly) after the orignal game (specifically the DLC 'The Writer) American Nightmare tells a the story of Alan facing off against his dopple ganger Mr Strange in the fictional country town of Night Springs located in Arizona. There are manuscript pages which serves as an insight on what happened to the characters from the orignal Alan Wake, after the ending (although since the manuscripts are found inside the TV show it is debatable whether the events actually happend outside the TV world or not).Audio is quite good. Aside from some forgettable character's, the majority of the voice acting is great at instilling personality (especially Mr Scratch). Weapons sound decent like the orignal game. There are also some rock music as well which sound great during tesne fights. At non-combat moments, quiet music is played to instill a spooky atmosphere (although not as effective as the in the orignal game).Compared to the original 'Alan Wake', this game has a stronger focus on combat. Like the previous game, you need to shine your flashlight at enemies until the 'shadow dissapears from them before you can damage them with bullets. You can sprint longer than in the previous game as well as removing darkness from the taken faster as well.  There is a variety of weapons available including the familiar ones pistol, carbine, shotgun, flares, flash grenades, to new ones like crossbow, double barrelled shotgun and nailgun.  You only start off with a pistol and flashlight and you need to either find new weapons or unlock them from trunks. Weapon trunks only open when you have collected enough manuscript pages. Unlike the previous game, ammunition is plentiful and is regained through red containers attatched to walls, which also replenish themselves over time. There are also a few recognisable enemies such as the flying objects and the standard goons. New enemies include bird guys (switch between human and bird form), chainsaw guy and spiders (which all have unique attacks). Other parts of the gameplay involves moving around and collecting/activating items to move the plot. There are only 3 areas in the game rest stop, observatory and outdoor cinema area (which compared to the original game is quite small). The areas are split up and not connected like the previous game. You will also go through these areas three times (which can feel a bit cumbersome), although with some different encounters to spice things up. Another issue is that the game is quite short, taking only 4 hours for me to complete (just campaign) compared to the orginal Alana wake, which took 18 hours.There is also a survival mode available. You start with only one stage and you need to collect stars to unlock new stages. Stars are earned based on your score at the end of the stage. To increase your score you need to kill off enemies (which are basically the guys you faced in single player). Enemies come out in waves. At the start of the stage, you only have a flashlight and pistol. New weapons are scattered around the area as well as light sources (which serve as auto-healling). You also need to be awar of your score multiplier which: 1.gradually decreases 2. increases for each kill or successful dodge and 3. Reuces to zero when you get hit by an enemy.If you like more Alan Wake gameplay, namely combat, than get this game. If you wanted a game which is similar to the original Alan Wake ,ie. focuses on plot, you will be dissapointed.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												Alan Wake's American Nightmare was a great game to play.In comparison to the first- not everything is clouded in darkness, there are way more guns, the engine as a whole feels much, MUCH, more polished and fluid. There are also live action cut scenes which I thought were awesome!! I felt it brought the characters to life in a fun and authentic feeling way. The characters for Mr. Scratch, Alan, and Alice all looked very, very similar to their in-game rendered model.Starting with the guns & fighting: You now have multiple small arms and multiple long arms, similar to the 2 weapon slots in the first game. For small arms you have a nail gun, either an uzi or mac10, revolver, and 9mm semiauto. Long guns had the double barrel & pump shotguns, an M16, M4A1, crossbow, and hunting rifle. These are the ones I can remember off the top of my head, there may have been a few more, and a few I didn't unlock. The guns feel fairly good shooting, ammo was much too plentiful in the game as there are caches of ammo & batteries for the flashlight all over the place as you play. The flashlight was also changed in American Nightmare to no longer give the constant damage to the enemies's shield, handy when you're low or facing a single enemy, now you have to boost the flashlight to do any shield damage. The flashlight recharges super fast, however, and I rarely, rarely used batteries compared to the first game (also no flashlight upgrades).The enemies in this game were not too difficult, most still had shields and they actually made a few enemies have different mechanics than the first game which was greatly appreciated. The process of burning down the shield and plinking at the same human silhouettes got old quickly in the first. This introduces enemies who fly around as crows and turn into humans, attempting to ambush and avoid your gun fire, enemies who split if you focus your flashlight on them, and even spiders who die by gun fire or light, no shield made of darkness.Where the first game had great settings and characters, the 2nd falls flat. There are 3 locations for the whole game which was intended for the story, but man was it boring. Luckily each time you revisit a location the tasks at hand are fast forwarded a bit so you spend a lot less time in each area upon returning. There were 3 intractable characters you worked with during the game: a mechanic Emma (boring and over sexualized in appearance), an astrologer/scientist Dr. Rachel Meadows (also over sexualized in appearance), and a theater attendant/film maker named Serena (this time over sexualized via EXTREMELY sIutty dialogue). Mr. Scratch, your bestie, is the 4th character you really do anything with and he's pretty freakin funny in this game, I got a kick out of his♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥bagginess and his bad guy antics.I did not play nor had any interest in the survival/arena mode which seems to be a highlight in this game.To sum up AW vs AL:AN- Alan Wake has a better setting, story, and characters. Alan Wake: American Nightmares has a better game engine, graphics, guns, and enemies.I recommend both, it's just too bad they couldn't get the best of both games together.

												For the most part, Alan Wake's American Nightmare shares many of the same positives as the original Alan Wake. But there are some improvements. For one, the combat is much smoother than in the first one, it just seems to run better. But it also seems to be a tad bit easier, but that could just be the difficulty setting I chose (I chose normal, but there is no "Easy" in AN like there was in Alan Wake, making the Normal the easier of the two difficulty options). They've also done away with many of the horror-esque elements. I'd classify this as a thriller, more than anything else. All in game cut scenes have also been replaced with live-action ones, which I thought was very interesting. They're were well done too. The game does well as a stand alone, providing good closure for the events of the previous game, whilst simultaneously giving sufficient background information to those who haven't played the original. An afternoon well spent in my book. Pick it up if you enjoyed the original, or if you need something short, sweet, and very good to play.

It's shorter than the first game by a great deal, which is fair, considering it was meant to, but the story mode is lacking. It has you play the same scenarios three times IN A ROW, with a little variation. The story behind this is sound, as would be expected from a story about a writer, but it still feels wooden regardless. Or, indeed, like the developers got bored and thought, 'Hmm, how can we get this to market in the next eight seconds?'. Also, with no change to gaming mechanic, this lack of emphasis on story compared to the first one makes it feel a lot more like a mindless shooter. And I generally dislike mindless shooters, especially ones that give you what is essentially horde mode - and then don't add multiplayer, thus rendering it pointless.6.5/10. Just missed a 6 by being an Alan Wake game.

Posted: January 23, 2015
												Alan Wake's American Nightmare is the shorter expansion pack style follow up to the previous entry - Alan Wake. Utilising a more arcade-y gameplay style this time, the game features shorter stage style locations with a heavier focus on combat and a vastly expanded collection of weaponry. The gameplay is much smoother this time around to make the fights feel more fluid and energetic, this does detract from the eerie atmosphere somewhat, with Alan feeling more powerful than ever (to be fair he would be pretty battle hardened by now though) and the enemies being easier to take down it is hard to feel overwhelmed, which does detract from the horror side of things. Storywise the game features a less intricate plot - The general overview is the doppelganger of Alan created from the ending of the first game - Mr. Scratch - is on the lose and attempting to destroy everything important to Alan and he must stop him before that happens. Overall Alan Wake's American Nightmare is a great bite sized action thriller with plenty of replayability.

American Nightmare still has a similar method of storytelling as the main game, and now features a truly psychotic villain. Now assuming you've played Alan Wake, here's what's new in American Nightmare. There are several new enemies with unique abilities. Several new weapons. Since you have more ammo, you will also be fighting more enemies at any given time. The overall game has a more action-arcade feel to it. Posted: December 13, 2015
												*This review will contain some spoilers for the story of Alan Wake, as well as some gameplay spoilers for American Nightmare. Read at your own disgression!* Alan Wake´s American Nightmare is a spinoff-title to the original Alan Wake. While it shares a lot of similarities with its predecessor, there is a notable amount of changes and new stuff that one should be aware before considering playing it, as these changes and additions will decide whether this game works for you or not.The story takes place within an episode of the TV show "Night Springs" (basically the Twilight Zone of Videogames). Alan, still trapped within the Darkness of the Lake after the end of the first game (and its DLC, to be more precise), has now been trapped within one of his own stories, by none other than his doppelgänger, Mr. Scratch. Caught in a loop of endless repetition and constant torment by Scratch, Alan has to find a way to "break the circle" and return to the real world before his doppelgänger has completely overtaken his "real" life.The gameplay of American Nightmare, at first glance, is basically the same as it was in Alan Wake: You run around in comparatively small, open areas, defeat Taken, collect manuscript pages to fill in story details, and solve some (very easy) puzzles or try and reach a certain spot to advance the story, while occacionally watching TV, listening to the radio and talking to a handful of people. This all takes place on three maps: A Gas Station/Motel in the middle of the Arizonian Desert, an Observatory, and a Drive-in Theater. While each map is quite distinct from the others, you also have to revisit each map several times over the course of the game. While this is explained and justified quite well within the story, this still means that two-thirds of the campaign are repeated content (minor changes notwithstanding). Thankfully, the actual gameplay is good enough so that one can look past it.American Nightmare, gameplay-wise, improves on both Alan Wake´s enemy design and weapon selection. While the regular Taken are still the bread-and-butter of your combat enemies, there are also various new enemy types that demand some different strategies from the usual "shine your light on them, destroy their shield, and then shoot them". This includes Taken that are immune to your flashlight and instead split into smaller versions of themselves, Taken that flee by transforming into bird flocks, and Taken that throw "Darkness Grenades" into your direction, but keep their distance, among other enemy types. To counter them, Alan now also has access to a much larger arsenal, which gets unlocked the more manuscript pages you collect, so even if you don´t care about the story at all, you should still keep your eyes open for them. The new arsenal includes pistols, a SMG, an Assault Rifle, a Combat Shotgun, a crossbow which ignores the enemy shield, and a Nailgun, among others. Some stuff from Alan Wake also makes a return, like the flaregun and the flashbangs, but they have become quite a bit weaker, no longer insta-killing anything, but rather destroying their shields quickly (which is still useful, of course).The gameplay in general is alot less "survival" and much more action-orientated. You will pretty much never run out of ammo or flashlight batteries, individual enemies are alot less threatening than they used to but appear in bigger numbers, and there is alot less general "creepiness" in wandering around the desert (though that may just be me). The game, in all fairness, also doesn´t try to be a horror game, unless you count the psychological "threat to your very existence, a doppelgänger overtaking your life" angle. In that regard, your occasional encounters with Mr. Scratch are fun, he´s quite a cool and fun, if decidedly hammy, villain, but there´s unfortunately no fight against him, or any boss fight at all, for that matter, which feels like a wasted opportunity, given the more arcade-y gameplay.Once you´re done with the campaign, there´s also an Arcade Mode, in which you have to survive a certain amount of time on various maps while fending off enemies, raising your combo meter (by killing enemies and evading their attacks) and getting enough points to earn stars and unlock new and more difficult maps. Its quite fun (and more difficult than the main campaign ever gets), but probably not something that you will play for more than a few hours.Overall, I personally would recommend American Nightmare, especially if it´s at a discount. If you liked Alan Wake overall, but disliked its gameplay, you will probably like it. If you didn´t like Alan Wake or aren´t interested in the franchise at all, I would still say that you should check it out, but the game will probably not change your overall opinion on the series.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												American Nightmare is a stand alone expansion to Alan Wake from Remedy Entertainment. Originally an Xbox live title this has made its way over to the PC with a few tweaks. Graphics are not powerhouse hungry but its not going to make you vomit in disgust at its admitadly bland pallet. As this game is set mostly in the desert with minimal indoor environmets this game is no stranger to the colour brown. The PC version does look better than its console sibling with AA options and a HD texture pack.The gameplay is very similar to the main game with a familar over the shoulder third person camera with a reasonable FOV. Ok its a very console orientated FOV and this game does play better with a gamepad than a keyboard and mouse although you want cry and bang your head on the desk if you dont have a gamepad. So I would recommend plugging in a pad and scooting your chair back a tad for a more comforatable experience. The weapons have a nice feel to them, the traditional pistol, rifle and shotgun are back with interesting additions such as the nail gun. There is enough variety of weapons around and plenty of ammo to keep gameplay fresh. The flashlight returns to burn off the "Darkness" which acts as a shield to enemies making them imune to bullets. But like in the main game the enemies are vunerable to all forms of lights, whether this is car headlights, flares or the sun.The game lets face it is not very long. The story mode takes about 3/4 hours to complete but considering this started out as an xbox live arcade expansion this is not a bad thing. Especially when the game costs less than a pint. New to American Nightmare is an arcade mode. This is basically a horde mode escape the zombies make it till dawn affair. It has a couple of achievements and map unlocks but single player means its not something you are going to come back to.So should you buy it? Have you played Alan Wake? If not go pick that up. Its not expensive, has a great story in the style of Stephen King novels. This game is a bit of an oddball rounding off the story that a lot of people expected from the main game. If you have played the base game, then deffinately pick this up. Although a little repeptive in the story it provides a better finish to the story you got so into in the previous incarnation.

Posted: July 18, 2016
												Don't get this expecting a full game. It's roughly a DLC, but the intro to the story is bundled in with the main game (the two Special episodes), so it gains an Arcade mode to add a bit of substance. A word of warning: for about the first third of the game, I was worried that it was utterly, inexplicably terrible. Luckily, it's not. It is, though, mediocre, a bit tedious, and lacks the charm and depth of the original.The quickest way to explain it, in my mind, is that it feels like it was made by a different group with different priorities. Manuscript pages now unlock weapons, for no particularly well-defined reason. Ammo caches are scattered around the map, but this leads to some oddly low caps for items (5 flares, 5 flashbangs, 10 batteries). There's a bit more of an open-world feel, but the areas are small (you don't get a map, and realistically don't need one) and it leads to a lot of ugly invisible walls. There's a nice variety of new enemies, but generic enemies are basically all you fight (no 'boss battles' and just a few poltergeists). The villain is a fairly interesting character, but it feels like he doesn't really get his chance to shine (er, no pun intended - his TV bits are reasonably well done but his short appearances ingame are underwhelming).Now, most of these are tradeoffs - there's plenty that's different, but it's not objectively worse. The real problem, as far as I'm concerned, is that the story and the overall flow of the game - which are pretty directly connected - just don't work this time around, certainly not in the way that they did so well in the original.The entire game takes place in three areas, each of which has a living population of precisely one attractive woman, which considering that in theory Wake is doing all the writing is more than a bit weird (there's arguably an excuse for him, but then there's not for the developers). The central mechanic of properly 'setting up' significant story points from the manuscript is actually pretty neat, but it's hamstrung by another central mechanic which isn't explained well, runs contrary to the concept of Wake having to write a coherent story, and leads to a lot of the gameplay feeling like doing the same thing over and over again in a way that isn't particularly interesting.If you're looking for some more refined Alan Wake gameplay, this is a neat little DLC. If you're looking for a worthy continuation of the story, you might actually want to stay away. Overall, I'll give it a hesitant recommendation; there's a decent game under it all - it's just not Alan Wake.

Posted: July 4, 2016
												At the end of Alan Wake, we were promised that “Alan Wake’s journey through the night will continue.” Naturally, I believed that meant a sequel somewhere in the near future, so when Alan Wake’s American Nightmare was announced, I assumed it was that sequel. Rather than being a sequel, however, American Nightmare is more of an Alan Wake 1.5, a DLC-like expansion (think Red Dead Redemption’s Undead Nightmare or Infamous: Second Son’s First Light) that slightly continues the plot of the original, while still managing to ask more questions than give answers.That in itself doesn’t sound very impressive, except perhaps for the die-hard Alan Wake cultists. However, in some important ways, American Nightmare is better than the original.One of my biggest complaints of the original game was the dodge button, which rarely ever worked for me. In American Nightmare, it works almost flawlessly. Also, batteries recharge almost instantly. I don’t think I changed the battery more than twice in my entire play through, including all the challenges. With such a large focus placed on mobility in fights, these are extremely useful and welcome changes.The areas to explore are much smaller than in Alan Wake, but I like how they still have a very large feel to them. Once again, there are manuscript pages to find, but locating them is much easier: Instead of solely hunting for glowing sheets of paper, when you get close enough to one, it appears on the mini-map as a circled question mark. Like in the previous entry, collecting manuscript pages give deeper insight to the story, but now they also allow you to unlock cases with high powered weapons in both the story and challenges. Thanks to being more convenient to find, players don’t have to worry about feeling outmatched by the more powerful Taken.What makes this game really shine, however, are the challenges (and the new Poets of the Fall songs). You spawn in one of multiple areas, none of which are directly from the story, and are tasked with fighting back the Taken until the sun comes up (ten minutes). Defeating Taken in rapid succession increases your score multiplier, and getting hit by them resets it. The trick is balancing picking up finite ammo, weapons, flares, and flashbangs while blasting unlimited (and strengthening) waves of Taken. I had an absolute blast with this mode—the maps all feel different but fun and even more inspired than the areas in the story. There’s not much sweeter than the adrenaline rush of having a map-full of Taken and your score multiplier maxed at 9x when the sun finally comes up and blows them all away. I would not be surprised at all if people unfamiliar with Alan Wake were drawn into the franchise by this mode alone.That all being said, I’m not a huge fan of the way the main story treads over the same/similar ground for three acts. Without spoiling anything, there are three areas in the game, and you visit them each three times throughout the story, completing almost identical objectives every time. Granted, it could have been handled far, far worse—there are enough changes each time to keep things from getting redundant and stale—but this design choice borders on development limitation, not plotline necessity. Fortunately, this would probably be something avoided in a true sequel.At the end of American Nightmare we are, once again, promised that “Alan Wake’s journey through the night will continue.” While American Nightmare is a worthy appetizer for fans of the original, we are still hungry for that promise to be fulfilled once again. Because, after all, for those who believe in the power of imagination, there are things that can only happen…in Night Springs.

Overall the story is nowhere near as good as the first game due to the 'time loop' scenario restraining them from doing any real progress.As well, the atmosphere suffers greatly from your trusty revolver and shotgun with limited ammo becoming full auto combat shotguns, submachine guns, assault rifles, and carbines, with boxes that 100% fill your ammo and batteries. It becomes a straight 3rd person shooter with a flashlight gimmick which is unfortunate. That said, the game adds a few more enemy types to make up for your increased firepower, so at least some thought went into the game here.It seems that about half of the game's achievements focus around the Arcade portion of the game. Posted: February 26, 2015
												A brief nightmare...Alan Wake's American Nightmare is a third person shooter developed by Remedy (Max Payne and Alan Wake creators). It is a standalone game, set in the 'Alan Wake' Universe. You play as Alan Wake, a writer who has gotten stuck in a television series called 'Night Springs'.The plot doesn't have a significant impact on the original story. Continuing (if somewhat loosly) after the orignal game (specifically the DLC 'The Writer) American Nightmare tells a the story of Alan facing off against his dopple ganger Mr Strange in the fictional country town of Night Springs located in Arizona. There are manuscript pages which serves as an insight on what happened to the characters from the orignal Alan Wake, after the ending (although since the manuscripts are found inside the TV show it is debatable whether the events actually happend outside the TV world or not).Audio is quite good. Aside from some forgettable character's, the majority of the voice acting is great at instilling personality (especially Mr Scratch). Weapons sound decent like the orignal game. There are also some rock music as well which sound great during tesne fights. At non-combat moments, quiet music is played to instill a spooky atmosphere (although not as effective as the in the orignal game).Compared to the original 'Alan Wake', this game has a stronger focus on combat. Like the previous game, you need to shine your flashlight at enemies until the 'shadow dissapears from them before you can damage them with bullets. You can sprint longer than in the previous game as well as removing darkness from the taken faster as well.  There is a variety of weapons available including the familiar ones pistol, carbine, shotgun, flares, flash grenades, to new ones like crossbow, double barrelled shotgun and nailgun.  You only start off with a pistol and flashlight and you need to either find new weapons or unlock them from trunks. Weapon trunks only open when you have collected enough manuscript pages. Unlike the previous game, ammunition is plentiful and is regained through red containers attatched to walls, which also replenish themselves over time. There are also a few recognisable enemies such as the flying objects and the standard goons. New enemies include bird guys (switch between human and bird form), chainsaw guy and spiders (which all have unique attacks). Other parts of the gameplay involves moving around and collecting/activating items to move the plot. There are only 3 areas in the game rest stop, observatory and outdoor cinema area (which compared to the original game is quite small). The areas are split up and not connected like the previous game. You will also go through these areas three times (which can feel a bit cumbersome), although with some different encounters to spice things up. Another issue is that the game is quite short, taking only 4 hours for me to complete (just campaign) compared to the orginal Alana wake, which took 18 hours.There is also a survival mode available. You start with only one stage and you need to collect stars to unlock new stages. Stars are earned based on your score at the end of the stage. To increase your score you need to kill off enemies (which are basically the guys you faced in single player). Enemies come out in waves. At the start of the stage, you only have a flashlight and pistol. New weapons are scattered around the area as well as light sources (which serve as auto-healling). You also need to be awar of your score multiplier which: 1.gradually decreases 2. increases for each kill or successful dodge and 3. Reuces to zero when you get hit by an enemy.If you like more Alan Wake gameplay, namely combat, than get this game. If you wanted a game which is similar to the original Alan Wake ,ie. focuses on plot, you will be dissapointed.

Posted: November 3, 2014
												Quick review:  Should you play this game? - Yes.  Will you enjoy it as much as the original Alan Wake? - Probably not, but you'll still have fun.-------------------------What I enjoyed:* Additional, powerful weapons made me feel like a one-man army.  * Excellent visual quality.* Interesting storyline that ties into the original.* Well-executed live-action components sequences.  * Mr. Scratch (!!!)My critique: I purchased both Alan Wake and the American Nightmare sequel in a bundle, so I was able to play the sequel soon after completing the original game.  Perhaps I should have given some time between the two games, because the transition between the two games was a bit jarring.  American Nightmare, despite the name, lacked much of the horror atmosphere that kept me addicted to the previous game.  It was the little things; like Alan making self-referential wise cracks about his supposedly very serious mission, the much easier enemies, and the dead-panned voice acting of the NPCs.  I did not get the impression that Alan was fighting for his life and that of his wife against an unrelenting horrific force of darkness, but rather this was just something he did that was mildly irritating.  As in: "Eh, it's a job...  BLAM! BLAM! BLAM!!!"As for the enemies being weaker, I mean that their darkness was broken much quicker, allowing them to be killed sooner.  A large part of what made Alan Wake challenging was the time needed to weaken enemies before they could be killed.  That gamepley mechanic created many tense situations where I had to dodge an onslaught of enemies while struggling to consistently shine a light on each one, before I could even start to kill them.  This was especially tricky if I ran out of batteries in the middle of the fight, which made the eventual victory all the more rewarding.  In American Nightmare, this feature is weakened, in that I was able to break almost every enemy's darkness before they came within swinging distance of me.  Regretably, this game was also much shorter than the previous one, and I was a bit surprised when I beat it so quickly.  I literally played through the entire campaign in 5 hours.  Now, I did enjoy most of that time, but I was surprised when it ended so soon.  I am not even sure if the campaign is worth playing a second time, because I saw just about every detail available in the 3 main levels the storyline loops you through.  And regarding the games looping storyline, I did enjoy the idea of Alan continually improving his strategy on each attempt and how the NPCs started to realize something was up on the second iteration.  I was fondly reminded of the movie "Groundhog Day".  However, the third iteration did not add much more to the story, as both Alan and myself were thinking, "Uh, I have to repeat this all over again..."  Right up until the game ended (too soon), I was hoping there would be more levels and another twist to the story.  Then at the ending scene, I realized that the game's developers had cleverly found a way to make a very short game three times as long...  by making you play it three times over.  Despite all of this, I DO recommend this game to anyone who has played the original Alan Wake or is just looking for a fun action game with some light horror undertones.  I had fun playing it, which is ultimately what I am looking for in any game.

												*This review will contain some spoilers for the story of Alan Wake, as well as some gameplay spoilers for American Nightmare. Read at your own disgression!* Alan Wake´s American Nightmare is a spinoff-title to the original Alan Wake. While it shares a lot of similarities with its predecessor, there is a notable amount of changes and new stuff that one should be aware before considering playing it, as these changes and additions will decide whether this game works for you or not.The story takes place within an episode of the TV show "Night Springs" (basically the Twilight Zone of Videogames). Alan, still trapped within the Darkness of the Lake after the end of the first game (and its DLC, to be more precise), has now been trapped within one of his own stories, by none other than his doppelgänger, Mr. Scratch. Caught in a loop of endless repetition and constant torment by Scratch, Alan has to find a way to "break the circle" and return to the real world before his doppelgänger has completely overtaken his "real" life.The gameplay of American Nightmare, at first glance, is basically the same as it was in Alan Wake: You run around in comparatively small, open areas, defeat Taken, collect manuscript pages to fill in story details, and solve some (very easy) puzzles or try and reach a certain spot to advance the story, while occacionally watching TV, listening to the radio and talking to a handful of people. This all takes place on three maps: A Gas Station/Motel in the middle of the Arizonian Desert, an Observatory, and a Drive-in Theater. While each map is quite distinct from the others, you also have to revisit each map several times over the course of the game. While this is explained and justified quite well within the story, this still means that two-thirds of the campaign are repeated content (minor changes notwithstanding). Thankfully, the actual gameplay is good enough so that one can look past it.American Nightmare, gameplay-wise, improves on both Alan Wake´s enemy design and weapon selection. While the regular Taken are still the bread-and-butter of your combat enemies, there are also various new enemy types that demand some different strategies from the usual "shine your light on them, destroy their shield, and then shoot them". This includes Taken that are immune to your flashlight and instead split into smaller versions of themselves, Taken that flee by transforming into bird flocks, and Taken that throw "Darkness Grenades" into your direction, but keep their distance, among other enemy types. To counter them, Alan now also has access to a much larger arsenal, which gets unlocked the more manuscript pages you collect, so even if you don´t care about the story at all, you should still keep your eyes open for them. The new arsenal includes pistols, a SMG, an Assault Rifle, a Combat Shotgun, a crossbow which ignores the enemy shield, and a Nailgun, among others. Some stuff from Alan Wake also makes a return, like the flaregun and the flashbangs, but they have become quite a bit weaker, no longer insta-killing anything, but rather destroying their shields quickly (which is still useful, of course).The gameplay in general is alot less "survival" and much more action-orientated. You will pretty much never run out of ammo or flashlight batteries, individual enemies are alot less threatening than they used to but appear in bigger numbers, and there is alot less general "creepiness" in wandering around the desert (though that may just be me). The game, in all fairness, also doesn´t try to be a horror game, unless you count the psychological "threat to your very existence, a doppelgänger overtaking your life" angle. In that regard, your occasional encounters with Mr. Scratch are fun, he´s quite a cool and fun, if decidedly hammy, villain, but there´s unfortunately no fight against him, or any boss fight at all, for that matter, which feels like a wasted opportunity, given the more arcade-y gameplay.Once you´re done with the campaign, there´s also an Arcade Mode, in which you have to survive a certain amount of time on various maps while fending off enemies, raising your combo meter (by killing enemies and evading their attacks) and getting enough points to earn stars and unlock new and more difficult maps. Its quite fun (and more difficult than the main campaign ever gets), but probably not something that you will play for more than a few hours.Overall, I personally would recommend American Nightmare, especially if it´s at a discount. If you liked Alan Wake overall, but disliked its gameplay, you will probably like it. If you didn´t like Alan Wake or aren´t interested in the franchise at all, I would still say that you should check it out, but the game will probably not change your overall opinion on the series.
